sourceDesc.bibl: "St. George" [Frances Shayle George]. The Kauri Forest. New Zealander, 5 October 1853, p. 3.

projectDesc.p: Transcribed and encoded as part of Settler Literature and Environmental Change in Australia and New Zealand," Marsden Fund Standard Grant 19-MAU-022 (Te Apārangi Royal Society of New Zealand).

lg.l: They raised their stately heads in pride,
O’er all the forest trees, O’er all the forest trees. Kauri is the tallest tree species in Aotearoa New Zealand, growing forty or fifty meters in height.
Their shadows lingered on the tide

Of circumambient seas; Circumambient seas. Likely a poetic description of New Zealand’s island geography, but possibly a reference to the coastal forests that were the earliest basis of the kauri trade.
The bright sun kissed them as he rose
High in the orient heaven,
To them, at daylight’s lovliest close,
His parting beams were given.
In velvet glades, by gushing streams,
Their giant growth was found,
Such has been dreamt in poet’s dreams,
And called enchanted ground;
No human foot, no human hand, No human foot, no human hand. The poem ignores Māori knowledge and use of kauri, and their according of chiefly status to the tallest kauri trees.
Those virgin groves had soiled,
Fresh as they sprang at God’s command,
When Earth’s first morning smil’d.
Profoundest silence shrined them round,
The air itself breathed awe,
The faintest sigh, the lightest sound,
Broke Nature’s mystic law.
Where are those silent forests now?
Keen axes Keen axes. Europeans had begun kauri milling in earnest by the 1820s. glance and ring,
While loud beneath each sheltering bough
The hardy woodsmen sing.
They make the freight of gallant barks, Freight of gallant barks. By the mid-1800s, kauri timber was being exported to Sydney and San Francisco for housing construction.
To many a distant shore,
And many a foreign landsman marks
The stately height they bore.
But never can man’s art restore
Those beauties once profan’d,
Those forests wear the garb they wore
When priceless Nature reign’d.

body.p: Auckland, Auckland. Kauri was restricted to the Auckland Province, in the north of the North Island, with notable forests in the vicinity of the Auckland settlement. October 3rd, 1853.
